awd_titl_txt: CEDAR: Atmospheric Coupling via Energetic Electron Precipitation (EEP)
awd_abstract_narration:
The award would study the downward transport from the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) of reactive nitrogen species (NOx) that are generated within the Arctic. The award would concentrate upon the study of an event that happened in the Arctic spring of 2004 for which an enormous influx of NOx from the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) was observed to enter the polar stratosphere, thus increasing the NOx mixing ratios in the upper stratosphere by a factor of 4.  This action in turn caused for those altitudes localized catalytic reductions in ozone of more than 60%. The processes leading to this influx, which were initiated by energetic electron precipitation (EEP), occur routinely and they have not yet been satisfactorily modeled. The proposed work would improve the understanding of EEP effects on the atmosphere in general, and the coupling between the MLT and the lower atmosphere in particular. 
A comprehensive description of Sun-Earth connections requires the quantification of the atmospheric processes that indirectly amplify the effects of solar and magnetospheric input. This includes nonlinear feedbacks between chemical, radiative, and dynamical processes that couple different regions of the atmosphere. The atmospheric response to EEP is a key component of Sun-Earth connections and provides a natural means of probing the underlying physics. This award would address an obvious deficiency with regard to the explanation and prediction of the effects of EEP on the atmosphere. 

The Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model (WACCM) developed by the National Center of Atmospheric Research would be used in conjunction with observations from numerous instruments to answer four primary questions: 1) Why does WACCM underestimate the amount of reactive odd nitrogen (NOx) that descended from the MLT during the Arctic winter of 2003-2004; 2)How well does it perform during other Arctic and Antarctic winters? 3), Given the extreme variability in the polar region, what statistical data sets are optimal for examining the atmospheric coupling processes that are relevant to EEP? and 4) What are the atmospheric effects of EEP after auroral electron precipitation and after higher energy electron precipitation?

por.por_cntn:
Energetic electron precipitation (EEP) is the process by which electrons from the earth's magnetosphere flow down into the atmosphere. These precipitating electrons ionize and dissociate atmospheric atoms and molecules, leading to a cascade of chemical reactions that changes the atmospheric composition. In particular, EEP leads to the production of reactive odd nitrogen (NOx) in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT). Observational and theoretical studies have shown that during the dark polar winter, NOx can descend into the stratosphere, where it destroys ozone. This is important since ozone helps to control temperatures in the stratosphere, which can affect the overall circulation and maybe even weather at the surface.

 

The overarching goal of this project was to clarify the impacts of EEP on the atmosphere, and the EEP-relevant coupling between the MLT and the stratosphere. The work targeted a longstanding puzzle in the aeronomy community:  Whole atmosphere models routinely underestimate the descent of NOx produced by EEP (EEP-NOx) on the atmosphere. One hypothesis was that this underestimate was caused by the fact that whole atmosphere models only included auroral electron precipitation, and did not include medium energy electron (MEE) precipitation. Auroral electrons are those with energies less than about 30 keV; they deposit their energy in the thermosphere. Medium energy electrons are those with energies from about 30-1000 keV; they deposit their energy mainly in the MLT, closer to the stratosphere than the auroral electrons.

 

To test this hypothesis, we developed a new data set that is now being used to specify MEE precipitation in whole atmosphere models. The data set is named "MPE", for "MEPED Precipitating Electrons". MEPED refers to the Medium Energy Proton and Electron Detector series of satellite instruments. We simulated the southern hemisphere winter of 2003 using the Whole Atmosphere Community Climate Model (WACCM), and compared the simulated EEP-NOx descent to observations. For this experiment we ran two simulations; one included only auroral electron precipitation and the other both auroral and MEE precipitation, with MEE precipitation specified by the MPE data set. We showed that including MEE precipitation by incorporating the MPE data improved the model-measurement comparisons. The simulation with MEE showed that the EEP-NOx caused ozone loss of more than 15% near 30 km altitude in the springtime polar stratosphere.

 

We also used WACCM to simulate the northern hemisphere winter of 2003-2004. Previous observational work had shown exceptionally large amounts of NOx descending into the stratosphere during this winter, but models were incapable of simulating this large influx. It had been hypothesized that the underestimate was caused not only by the lack of MEE precipitation in the model, but also by errors in transporting EEP-NOx into the stratosphere. The southern hemisphere experiment described above suggested that our MPE data improved the simulated production of EEP-NOx by precipitating electrons, so applying the MPE data to simulating the northern 2003-2004 winter was a test of the model transport. We found that EEP-NOx descent in the simulation with MPE matched observations better than the simulation without MPE, but there were still significant deficiencies. Our hypothesis, which remains to be tested in future work, is that the model needs an improved representation of atmospheric gravity waves. Gravity waves are an important factor for controlling atmospheric circulation, and thus transport of EEP-NOx. These waves have small enough spatial scales, however, that their effects are parameterized in whole atmosphere models; so they are a large source of uncertainty in the simulations.

 

This project supported the PhD dissertation and postdoctoral work of one student. Through this project he gained substantial experience with the MEPED data, and with running, modifying, and analyzing output from WACCM. The experience positioned him well for future opportunities, and led to his current position at a NASA center. He presented his work in group meetings as well as in professional venues. He attended seminars and networked with colleagues in the local region, especially at the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) and NOAA. He received guidance on writing scientific publications and proposals and giving presentations. Through regular group meetings he was introduced to scientific areas outside his own expertise, and through his attendance at external conferences and workshops he was introduced to members of the community. Within the university he worked with less experienced students, gaining mentoring experience of his own; he also supported undergraduate classroom activities. In addition to the PhD dissertation, 5 peer-reviewed publications and 14 presentations (7 invited) were supported partially or entirely by this grant.
